stories.story: I remember the morning I cleaned Mrs. Evans’s house after her husband passed. The sun was just coming up, and the rooms felt heavy with silence. I polished the old piano, dusted the family photos, and made sure the kitchen sparkled. Mrs. Evans sat at the table, watching me, and I brewed her a cup of tea. We talked quietly, and I listened more than I spoke. That day, I learned that caring for a home is sometimes the best way to care for a heart.

There was a morning, years ago, when I cleaned for Mrs. Evans after her husband died. The house was quiet, and I worked slowly, dusting, polishing, making tea. She sat at the table, and we talked a little. I remember thinking how much comfort a clean home can bring.
I once cleaned for a woman—Mrs. Evans, I think—after her husband passed. The house was quiet. I dusted, made tea. We talked some. It felt important, just being there.
There was a day, a house, a woman. I cleaned. We talked. I remember the quiet.
A house. A woman. I cleaned.
